t: To the Chief Musician. On an instrument of Gath. A Psalm of Asaph.
Sing*pn aloud to God our strength; Make*ld a joyful shout to the God of Jacob.
Raise*ld a song and strike the timbrel, The*ld pleasant harp with the lute.
Blow*ln the trumpet at the time of the New Moon, At*ld the full moon, on our solemn feast day.
For*ld this is*i a statute for Israel, A*ld law of the God of Jacob.
This*ld He established in Joseph as*i a testimony, When*ld He went throughout the land of Egypt, Where*ild I heard a language I did not understand.
“I*ln removed his shoulder from the burden; His*ld hands were freed from the baskets.
You*ld called in trouble, and I delivered you; I*ld answered you in the secret place of thunder; I*ld tested you at the waters of Meribah. Selah*ipg
“Hear,*pn O My people, and I will admonish you! O*ld Israel, if you will listen to Me!
There*ld shall be no foreign god among you; Nor*ld shall you worship any foreign god.
I*ld am*i the Lord*s your God, Who*ld brought you out of the land of Egypt; Open*ld your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
“But*ln My people would not heed My voice, And*ld Israel would have*i none of Me.
So*ld I gave them over to their own stubborn heart, To*ld walk in their own counsels.
“Oh,*ln that My people would listen to Me, That*ld Israel would walk in My ways!
I*ld would soon subdue their enemies, And*ld turn My hand against their adversaries.
The*ld haters of the Lord*s would pretend submission to Him, But*ld their fate would endure forever.
He*ld would have fed them also with the finest of wheat; And*ld with honey from the rock I would have satisfied you.”
